metadata.case_name: Durga Charan Naik & Ors. v. State

facts.text: Decree-holders Panu Sahu and Naha Sahu levied execution of decree Ex. Case No. 125/62 in Court of Munsif, Puri against appellants (judgment-debtors).
Writ of attachment of moveables issued to PW 2 Sadhu Charan Mohanty, peon, returnable by August 10, 1962.
PW 2 reached village of judgment-debtors on August 10, 1962 at 10 a.m., asked for decretal dues of Rs. 952-10 nP, about to seize moveables when appellants came with lathis and resisted.
PW 2 sent report Ex. 4 to Court requesting police help.
Munsif wrote letter Ex. 2 to Superintendent of Police, Puri for police help to Officer-in-charge, Sadar Police Station.
PW 1 (Assistant Sub-Inspector, Sadar PS) deputed with two constables including PW 3, accompanied by PW 6 (Naib Sarpanch) and PW 8 (Chowkidar).
Police party found PW 2 at house of Durga Charan Naik; Fakir Charan Naik (father) paid Rs. 952-10 nP to PW 2, receipt obtained.
Party left village; at about 7 p.m. while crossing river in boat, PW 1 saw appellant Durga Charan with 10-12 persons approaching.
PW 1 directed PW 2 to hand money to chowkidar PW 8.
On getting down from boat, Durga Charan forcibly dragged PW 1 (ASI), threatened assault if money not returned, searched pockets.
Netrananda threatened PW 1, obstructed him from writing report by holding right hand.
Bipra and Jugal caught hold of hands of PW 2, took him to river bank, demanded return of money; snatched his bag.
At intervention of outsiders, appellants left spot.
PW 1 lodged FIR next morning; after investigation, appellants charge-sheeted and committed to Sessions Court.
Appellants charged under ss. 143/402 IPC (unlawful assembly for dacoity); Durga Charan, Jugal, Bipra +3 under s. 186 IPC; Durga Charan & Netrananda under s. 353 IPC; Bipra & Jugal under s. 353 IPC.
Additional Sessions Judge acquitted appellants of all charges.

State appealed to Orissa High Court (Govt Appeal No. 49/1963); High Court set aside acquittal for 4 appellants, convicted under s. 353 IPC, sentenced to 4 months RI; no conviction under 143/402; s.186 barred by s.195 CrPC.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the Additional Sessions Judge under s. 353 IPC.
Whether conviction under s. 353 IPC is vitiated due to contravention of s. 195(1) CrPC, as it circumvents the requirement for complaint in writing needed for s. 186 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court had no justification for interfering with acquittal order; did not apply correct principles; no evidence of criminal force against PW 1 and 2.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principles from Sheo Swarup case; appellate power in acquittal appeals

petitioner_arguments.text: Conviction under s. 353 IPC illegal as it contravenes s. 195(1) CrPC; same facts as s. 186 IPC which requires written complaint; amounts to circumvention.

court_reasoning.text: High Court relied on evidence of PW 1,2,3 and PW 9-13; PW 2 entrusted with writ execution and carrying money; PW 1 assisting; both assaulted while discharging duties as public servants.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants used criminal force: Durga caught PW1, threatened; Bipra/Jugal caught PW2, snatched bag.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly analysed trial court reasoning and found acquittal unjustified; appellate court full power to review evidence in acquittal appeals.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principles from Sanwat Singh v. State of Rajasthan and M.G. Agarwal v. State of Maharashtra applied.

court_reasoning.text: ss. 186 and 353 IPC are distinct offences: s.186 is obstruction (non-cognizable), s.353 requires criminal force/assault (cognizable); different chapters in IPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.195 CrPC does not bar trial for distinct offence on same facts if not within s.195 ambit.

court_reasoning.text: No evasion or camouflage; prosecution under s.353 not misdescription of s.186 offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Precedents like Satis Chandra, Basir-ul-Huq, Hori Ram Singh support separate cognizance.

holdings.text: High Court justified in reversing acquittal under s.353 IPC; evidence supports use of criminal force by appellants against public servants PW1 and PW2.
s.195 CrPC does not bar trial under s.353 IPC even on same facts as s.186 IPC, as they are distinct offences.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sanwat Singh & Ors. v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Appellate court power to review evidence and reverse acquittal if not justified.
Principles for appellate approach to acquittal appeals.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. G. Agarwal & M. K. Kulkarni v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Wide powers in appeals against acquittal same as conviction; no rigid formula required.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satis Chandra Chakravarti v. Ram Dayal De
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinct offences on same facts can be separately prosecuted if one not requiring sanction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Basir-ul-Huq & Ors. v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: s.195 does not bar distinct offence against private individual even if same facts involve public servant offence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinct offences in same transaction; lack of sanction for one does not bar other.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction under s.353 for using criminal force to public servant; distinct from s.186 obstruction; no for 143/402.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Procedure Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires complaint for s.186; does not bar s.353 as distinct offence.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, upheld Orissa High Court's judgment convicting four appellants under s.353 IPC and sentencing them to 4 months rigorous imprisonment, finding High Court justified in reversing acquittal and no bar under s.195 CrPC.

key_quotes.text: It is well-established that s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code does not bar the trial of an accused person for a distinct offence disclosed by the same set of facts but which is not within the ambit of that section.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding distinguishing ss.186 and 353 IPC.

key_quotes.text: The High Court has mainly relied upon the evidence of P.Ws 1, 2 and 3 and P.Ws 9 to 13 for holding that the appellants used criminal force against P.Ws 1 and 2.
key_quotes.speaker: court
